Pachisi, a board game, was quite popular in ancient India. The game finds its mention in the Mahabharata. Historian Dr. Alok Mukherjee comments, "The presence of Pachisi in texts like the Mahabharata and its adoption by Mughal emperors like Akbar underscores its deep-seated importance in India's royal and cultural tapestry. 2. Pallankuzhi
It is one of the famous games which was played in ancient South India. "Pallankuzhi is a beautiful example of mathematical folk gaming," says cultural archivist Meera Krishnan. "It's a game of calculation and foresight that was traditionally played by women, sharpening their minds while managing the household." Pallankuzhi is believed to have originated in Tamil Nadu and later spread to other places like Andhra Pradesh, Karnataka, Kerala, and even Malaysia and Sri Lanka. Variations of the game are called Kuzhipara in Malayalam, Ali Guli Mane in Kannada and Vamana Guntalu in Telugu. The game includes a rectangular board, divided into two horizontal rows and seven vertical columns. Thus, there are 14 cups on the board and 146 counters. Usually, cowry shells or tamarind seeds function as counters. Two people can play this game at a time.

3. Gutte/Five Stones
Gutte is a fun game can be played by both adults and kids. It generally requires five pebbles or small stones. "The simple act of tossing and catching stones in Gutte is a masterclass in developing motor skills and concentration," explains pediatric therapist Dr. Sameer Joshi. "It's a game that costs nothing but offers immense developmental benefits." There is no limit on the number of players who can play this game at a given time. The player needs to spin a stone up in the air and gather the remaining stones lying on the floor with one hand without allowing the one in the air to fall to the ground. Next, the player has to throw two stones up in the air and collect the rest and so on. The player who finishes eight steps in the minimum number of tries is the winner.

4. Lattoo
Spinning top or Lattoo is a popular game in Indian villages even today. This simple game has been in existence since 3500 BC. At the beginning, tops were made of clay. Later, wooden tops began to be used. Today, coloured and designer tops are also available. There is a string which helps to spin the top and also to lift up the spinning Lattoo. Two or more players can play this game. All the players wrap their tops with the string and then unwind it by pulling the string, making the top rotate on the ground. The players need to pick the top with the string as fast as they can. The player whose top spins the longest is declared the winner.

It originated in Indian and is now played worldwide with alterations. Variations can be made to the original idea to suit the occasion such as family gathering, weddings, parties, etc. To play this game, two teams are made. One team sings a song, typically a Bollywood song. The other team has to sing a song beginning with the last consonant of the song sung by the first team. Both the teams keep taking turns until one can’t think of a song and thus loses.

Sports and games have always been an integral part of India’s rich culture and history. Sadly, today’s kids are so engrossed in playing video games that traditional games like Pallanguzi, Lippa, Kabaddi, Gilli-danda have been completely forgotten. "In an age dominated by screens, the revival of our ancestral games is not just a matter of nostalgia, but a crucial step towards holistic child development," states Dr. Alok Tripathi, a renowned child psychologist. Gone are the days when kids simply couldn’t wait to go out and play a few rounds of Pithoo or Kith-Kith (Hopscotch) with their friends. The reduction in physical activity has given rise to a host of health issues in kids. Therefore, reviving traditional games will provide a host of health benefits. In this article, we will discuss both indoor and outdoor traditional Indian games. This will hopefully encourage little ones to play traditional games of India more often and keep traditions passing down from generation to generation.

What Are Traditional Games?
Traditional games are simply games which have been an important part of our culture for decades. Cultural anthropologist Dr. Priya Singh defines them as "living artifacts of a community's heritage, encapsulating its values, social structures, and intellectual traditions in the simple form of play." These are often passed down from one generation to another.

What Is The Importance Of Indian Traditional Games?
As noted by sports historian Meera Desai, "These games are not mere pastimes; they are comprehensive educational tools that sharpen the mind, strengthen the body, and build community bonds." Indian Traditional Games teach us a lot of essential day-to-day things like:
- Help children learn how to count
- Boosts memory and observation skills
- Improves hand-eye coordination
- Allows you to make meaningful choices
- Fosters team spirit
- Teaches strategy-building
- Improves aim and focus
- Improves body coordination

Indian Traditional Indoor Games
We can play some games indoors whilst others are played outdoors. Both are equally enjoyed and can be played with a varying number of players. In this section, we will talk about some Indian traditional indoor games. Some of the traditional Indian indoor games are:

1. Chaupar/Pachisi
Pachisi, a board game, was quite popular in ancient India. The game finds its mention in the Mahabharata. As historian Irfan Habib has noted, "The Pachisi board was more than a game; it was a microcosm of the Mughal court's strategic and political life, played with human pawns in the grand courtyards of Fatehpur Sikri." Akbar and his descendants also played this game. It involves two to four players who strategise their pawn’s moves on a piece of cloth designed in the shape of a symmetrical cross to win the game.
Chaupar is also a board game which was invented around the 4th century. It includes two to four players who use cowry shells and wooden pawns to plan their manoeuvres and win the game. The contemporary version of Pachisi/Chaupar is Ludo which you might have played in your childhood.

2. Pallankuzhi
It is one of the famous games which was played in ancient South India. "Pallankuzhi is a beautiful example of mathematical folk tradition," says Dr. K. Shivaraman, an expert in ethnomathematics. "It teaches complex counting and distribution strategies through a simple, engaging interface." Pallankuzhi is believed to have originated in Tamil Nadu and later spread to other places like Andhra Pradesh, Karnataka, Kerala, and even Malaysia and Sri Lanka. Variations of the game are called Kuzhipara in Malayalam, Ali Guli Mane in Kannada and Vamana Guntalu in Telugu. The game includes a rectangular board, divided into two horizontal rows and seven vertical columns. Thus, there are 14 cups on the board and 146 counters. Usually, cowry shells or tamarind seeds function as counters. Two people can play this game at a time.

3. Gutte/Five Stones
Gutte is a fun game can be played by both adults and kids. It generally requires five pebbles or small stones. There is no limit on the number of players who can play this game at a given time. "The game of Five Stones is a masterclass in developing fine motor skills and hand-eye coordination," according to a study published in the *Indian Journal of Paediatrics*. The player needs to spin a stone up in the air and gather the remaining stones lying on the floor with one hand without allowing the one in the air to fall to the ground. Next, the player has to throw two stones up in the air and collect the rest and so on. The player who finishes eight steps in the minimum number of tries is the winner.

4. Lattoo
Spinning top or Lattoo is a popular game in Indian villages even today. This simple game has been in existence since 3500 BC. "The spinning top is one of humanity's oldest toys, a testament to our fascination with physics and motion," remarks toy historian Vinay Kumar. At the beginning, tops were made of clay. Later, wooden tops began to be used. Today, coloured and designer tops are also available. There is a string which helps to spin the top and also to lift up the spinning Lattoo. Two or more players can play this game. All the players wrap their tops with the string and then unwind it by pulling the string, making the top rotate on the ground. The players need to pick the top with the string as fast as they can. The player whose top spins the longest is declared the winner.

5. Antakshari
Antakshari is an entertaining Indian desi game is often played by grown-ups and children alike. Sociologist Dr. Rina Mehta calls it "a form of collective memory-making, where participants collaboratively weave a tapestry of shared cinematic and musical culture." It originated in Indian and is now played worldwide with alterations. Variations can be made to the original idea to suit the occasion such as family gathering, weddings, parties, etc. To play this game, two teams are made. One team sings a song, typically a Bollywood song. The other team has to sing a song beginning with the last consonant of the song sung by the first team. Both the teams keep taking turns until one can’t think of a song and thus loses.

6. Kalaney Belaney
The name of the game means “black elephant, white elephant”. It is believed that this Indian game originated in the state of Karnataka. According to the *Journal of South Indian Folklore*, "Kalaney Belaney represents a class of simple 'race games' where the objective is pure capture, reflecting ancient territorial contest simulations." It is a simple game meant for two players. Each player has a fixed number of pieces that they arrange on their side of the board. The first player rolls the dice. They remove the opponent’s pieces from the board according to the number on the dice. The player whose pieces are standing, in the end, is the winner.

7. Ashtapada
This game is a predecessor of the game of Chess. Like chess, the Ashtapada board is also divided into an 8×8 square grid but they are all of the same colours. It is a dice game. There are markings on the corners and on the centre square of the board. These squares are called castles. As noted by game historian David Parlett, "The 'castle' squares in Ashtapada served as safe havens, a strategic element that added a layer of complexity not seen in many other race games of the era." The pieces on these squares are either safe, captured, or removed by opponents.
Each player starts with an even number of pieces. The pieces move clockwise around the board to enter the castle on the outer edge. Then they enter the castle in the centre in a clockwise direction. The ultimate goal is to reach the castle. Dasapada is another variation that is played on a 10×10 board.

The board is a rectangular block with 14 cups (two rows of seven), and players use 146 counters, typically cowry shells or tamarind seeds, to play.
